description: BlackRock, the worldâ€™s largest asset manager, has launched its first Bitcoin product in Europe, a move that industry experts say will help legitimise cryptocurrencies in mainstream finance.Â  â€œThis is a landmark development for crypto, displaying confidence in Bitcoin for mainstream investments,â€ Meryem Habibi, chief revenue officer at London-based crypto paymentÂ gatewayÂ Bitpace, told TNW.Â  â€œThrough this first in Europe, BlackRock is not only legitimising the asset class but also paving the way for increased institutional and retail participation,â€ she said. ETPs let investors buy and sell Bitcoin without directly owning the cryptocurrency.â€¦This story continues at The Next WebOr just read more coverage about: Bitcoin

excerpt: BlackRock's first Bitcoin product in Europe is predicted to boost the asset's price and generate 'significant inflows' of institutional cash.
text: BlackRock, the worldâ€™s largest asset manager, has launched its first Bitcoin product in Europe, a move that industry experts say will help legitimise cryptocurrencies in mainstream finance.Â  â€œThis is a landmark development for crypto, displaying confidence in Bitcoin for mainstream investments,â€ Meryem Habibi, chief revenue officer at London-based crypto paymentÂ gatewayÂ Bitpace, told TNW.Â  â€œThrough this first in Europe, BlackRock is not only legitimising the asset class but also paving the way for increased institutional and retail participation,â€ she said. BlackRockâ€™s product is called an â€œiShares Bitcoin ETPâ€ (exchange-traded products). ETPs let investors buy and sell Bitcoin without directly owning the cryptocurrency. They are traded on stock exchanges and track the price of Bitcoin. Sign up now!This enables investments in Bitcoinâ€™s price movements through a traditional brokerage account without needing a digital wallet or dealing with the complexities of buying Bitcoin directly. â€œETPs offer institutional investors a way of accessing crypto without exposing themselves to the risks inherent in investing natively,â€ Anthony Yeung, CCO of Coincover, told TNW. This type of investment vehicle is gaining momentum globally. Investors have already poured a combined $50bn into BlackRockâ€™s Bitcoin ETPs in the US.Â  â€œIf BlackRockâ€™s success in the US is anything to go by, this will generate significant inflows of institutional cash [in Europe] â€” positively impacting Bitcoin price and helping drive acceptance of crypto as an essential asset to hold in a balanced portfolio,â€ Yeung said.Â  Europeâ€™s ETP landscape While Europe was slower to adopt ETPs than the US, it is now catching up. Thatâ€™s partly thanks to the EUâ€™s Markets in Crypto Assets (MiCA) regulation, which entered force late last year.Â  The legislation provides a clear and structured framework for launching new products. In the US, oversight is more fragmented. Last year, Europe had $12bn of ETP assets under management. While that still paled in comparison to the US ($57bn), it represents a tenfold increase from 2020 levels.Â  In terms of investment options, though, Europe hosts 135 ETPs â€” far more than the US (35).Â  The largest ETP issuers in Europe last year were the US-based CoinShares, Switzerlandâ€™s 21Shares, and London-headquartered ETC Group, according to Track Insight. James Burnie, fintech expert at British law firm gunnercooke, told TNW that BlackRockâ€™s entry into Europeâ€™s maturing ETP market is an added boost for the sector. â€œIt gets traditional finance comfortable with dealing in crypto assets,â€ he said.Â  â€œHowever, given that the crypto markets are now already considered a mainstay of finance, such moves are now becoming less impactful,â€ he added. â€œSoon the scrutiny will be more on any large traditional player not being in the industry.â€ Habibi echoes Burnieâ€™s sentiments about the sectorâ€™s maturity. She argues that BlackRockâ€™s move speaks to a wider trend of â€œblurring traditional finance with digital assets.â€Â  â€œCrypto is becoming more aligned with everyday finance,â€ she said.
html:
BlackRock, the worldâ€™s largest asset manager, has launched its first Bitcoin product in Europe, a move that industry experts say will help legitimise cryptocurrencies in mainstream finance.Â 

â€œThis is a landmark development for crypto, displaying confidence in Bitcoin for mainstream investments,â€ Meryem Habibi, chief revenue officer at London-based crypto paymentÂ gatewayÂ Bitpace, told TNW.Â 

â€œThrough this first in Europe, BlackRock is not only legitimising the asset class but also paving the way for increased institutional and retail participation,â€ she said.

BlackRockâ€™s product is called an â€œiShares Bitcoin ETPâ€ (exchange-traded products). ETPs let investors buy and sell Bitcoin without directly owning the cryptocurrency. They are traded on stock exchanges and track the price of Bitcoin.

The ğŸ’œ of EU tech

The latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!

This enables investments in Bitcoinâ€™s price movements through a traditional brokerage account without needing a digital wallet or dealing with the complexities of buying Bitcoin directly.

â€œETPs offer institutional investors a way of accessing crypto without exposing themselves to the risks inherent in investing natively,â€ Anthony Yeung, CCO of Coincover, told TNW.

This type of investment vehicle is gaining momentum globally. Investors have already poured a combined $50bn into BlackRockâ€™s Bitcoin ETPs in the US.Â 

â€œIf BlackRockâ€™s success in the US is anything to go by, this will generate significant inflows of institutional cash [in Europe] â€” positively impacting Bitcoin price and helping drive acceptance of crypto as an essential asset to hold in a balanced portfolio,â€ Yeung said.Â 

Europeâ€™s ETP landscape

While Europe was slower to adopt ETPs than the US, it is now catching up. Thatâ€™s partly thanks to the EUâ€™s Markets in Crypto Assets (MiCA) regulation, which entered force late last year.Â 

The legislation provides a clear and structured framework for launching new products. In the US, oversight is more fragmented.

Last year, Europe had $12bn of ETP assets under management. While that still paled in comparison to the US ($57bn), it represents a tenfold increase from 2020 levels.Â 

In terms of investment options, though, Europe hosts 135 ETPs â€” far more than the US (35).Â 

The largest ETP issuers in Europe last year were the US-based CoinShares, Switzerlandâ€™s 21Shares, and London-headquartered ETC Group, according to Track Insight.

James Burnie, fintech expert at British law firm gunnercooke, told TNW that BlackRockâ€™s entry into Europeâ€™s maturing ETP market is an added boost for the sector. â€œIt gets traditional finance comfortable with dealing in crypto assets,â€ he said.Â 

â€œHowever, given that the crypto markets are now already considered a mainstay of finance, such moves are now becoming less impactful,â€ he added. â€œSoon the scrutiny will be more on any large traditional player not being in the industry.â€

Habibi echoes Burnieâ€™s sentiments about the sectorâ€™s maturity. She argues that BlackRockâ€™s move speaks to a wider trend of â€œblurring traditional finance with digital assets.â€Â 

â€œCrypto is becoming more aligned with everyday finance,â€ she said.
